and whatsoever <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> <span class="t0 t6 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">shalt</span> bind on <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> shall be bound in heaven: and whatsoever <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> <span class="t0 t6 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">shalt</span> loose on <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> 
shall be loosed in heaven.’ 

13. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> will not leave you: Cf. Psalm 37:28. ‘For the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> loveth judgement, and forsaketh not his saints.’ 

14. you will see in his light: Cf. Psalm 36:9. 


15. Songs for the Dedication of a Church 


1. Arnold of Brescia: The suggestion is made by Barbara Newman in her Sister of <span class="t12 t20 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">Wisdom</span> and again in her 
Symphonia, 2nd edn (Ithaca, 1998), p. 315. 

2. O virgo ecclesia. Antiphon: Pudentiana Barth and Immaculata Ritscher (eds), Hildegard von Bingen. Lieder 
(Salzburg, 1969), no. 56 and Barbara Newman (ed.), Hildegard of Bingen. Symphonia, no. 66. The song uses 
traditional imagery of the Church as mother and bride of the King. 

3. banner of the king: I.e. the cross. 

4. Nunc gaudeant. Antiphon: Barth and Ritscher, Hildegard von Bingen. Lieder, no. 57 and Newman, 
Symphonia, no. 67. This song is the last piece in the Dendermonde manuscript. 


i6. Teachings on the Church (from Scivias) 


1. ‘unable and unwilling to be <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> it’: Arnold of Cologne to Hildegard (Letter 14). For the <span class="t5 hoverable">full</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">text</span> see 32. 
The letter must have been <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> before 1156, when Rainald of Dassel succeeded Arnold as Archbishop of 
Cologne. 

2. ‘The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> sent a word... it has lighted <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> Israel’: Isaiah 9:8. 

3. ‘Who are these... to their windows?’: Isaiah 60:8. Here Hildegard comments on the relationship of the 
Synagogue to the Church. The final version of The Play of the Virtues, which was issued in 1158, should be 
compared with this passage. The opening section of the prologue gives another <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> of the same verse, for now 
Hildegard imagines it spoken by the prophets and patriarchs of old rather than the Synagogue: 

PATRIARCHS AND PROPHETS: 

Who are these? Who are these that fly as a cloud? 

VIRTUES: 

Oh <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">holy</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> of Antiquity, why are you amazed at us? 

The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Word</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> shines bright in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> of a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> 

and so we shine with him, 

forming the limbs of his beautiful body. 

PATRIARCHS AND PROPHETS: 

We are the roots and you are the branches, 
the fruits of the living eye 
in which we were the shadow. 

See also Letter II to Hartwig of Bremen, Richardis’s brother (8), which uses the same <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">verse</span> from Isaiah. 

4. The bright radiance... hindrance: The concept of radiance <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> a gemstone is reminiscent of Hildegard’s 
treatment of gemstones in Physica, although the carbuncle is not included among the stones she discusses 
there. See 22. 

5. baptism: The need to provide teaching on sacraments such as baptism should be seen against the background 
of the Cathar movement, which rejected them. 

6. ways: Cf. the title of the <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> Scivias, usually interpreted as scito vias, i.e. ‘know the ways.’ 

7. travel on the road: The story recalls biblical parables, but also reflects the dangers of travel in the twelfth 
century. 

8. ‘And on the morrow... I will repay thee’: Luke 10:35, from the parable of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Good</span> Samaritan, who helps a 
traveller wounded by robbers and takes him to an inn to be looked after. 

9. “Well done you <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> and faithful servant”: Matthew 25:21. 

10. they are built not on rock but on sand: A clear link to the parable from the Sermon on the Mount in 
Matthew 7:24-7, where <span class="t0 t6 t8 t9 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t22 t23 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Jesus</span> tells the story of a <span class="t8 t12 t17 hoverable">wise</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> who built his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> on a foundation of rock while a 
foolish <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> built his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> on sand which fell down in the next storm and flood. 

11. [On oblates]: Oblates were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">children</span> dedicated to the monastic life, often at a very early age. Despite the <span class="t23 hoverable">high</span> 
regard she had for the monastic vocation, Hildegard approved of oblation only if the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">children</span> were given an 
opportunity to decide for themselves when old enough to make decisions. For more discussion of Hildegard’s 
imagery in this passage, see Introduction, III.i. 


17. Letter to Elisabeth of Schonau 


1. One important manuscript... Villers in Brabant: The manuscript is now preserved as Codex 9 of the library of 
the Benedictine monastery at Dendermonde in Belgium. 

2. vessel... perfected in it: Cf. II Corinthians 4:7: ‘But we have this treasure in earthen vessels, that the excellency 
of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> may be of God, and not of us.’ 

3 . Ach! Weh!: Hildegard’s cry of dismay, equivalent to ‘alas’ and ‘woe’, is spoken in German rather than Latin. 

4. become a complete mockery: Latin ‘derideretur’. 

5. ‘Thou <span class="t2 t6 t8 t9 t10 t15 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t28 t29 hoverable">art</span> fairer than the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">children</span> of men’: Psalm 45:2. 

6. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> of justice: Malachi 4:2. 

7. hour of the day: The hours of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> were particularly important in the daily <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of the monastery. 

8. soar over the clouds as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> they were gods: Isaiah 60:8 blended with Psalm 82:6. The same <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> biblical 
verses occur in the letter to Hartwig, Archbishop of Bremen (8). 

9. secrets of God: Latin ‘mystica Dei’. 

10. the breastplate of <span class="t4 t7 t12 t16 hoverable">faith</span> : I Thessalonians 5:8. 


18. Gertrud of Stahl eck 


1. bought a pearl: Matthew 13:46. See also Hildegard’s own parable of the pearl discussed in the Introduction at 
II.i. 

2. Gertrud: For Gertrud’s plea for help, see 32, Letter 62 to Hildegard. 

3. ‘the <span class="t23 hoverable">voice</span> of the turtledove is <span class="t13 t14 t15 t18 t27 hoverable">heard</span> in our land’: Song of Songs 2:12. 

4. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Therefore</span> rejoice... your heart: Zechariah 2:10 blended with Romans 8:9 or I Corinthians 3:16. 

5. ‘as a lily among thorns’: Song of Songs 2:2. 

6. which the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Son</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> thorns: Luke 8:14. A reference to the parable of the Sower. 

7. a wall... pearls: Revelation 21:18-21. 


19. Letter to the Abbess of Bamberg 


1. ‘the first degree of humility is obedience... <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Christ</span> Leonard J. Doyle (trans.), St Benedict’s Rule for 
Monasteries (Collegeville, MN, 1948), p. 18. 

2. Abbess of Bamberg: For the request from the Abbess to Hildegard, see 32, Letter 61. 


20. The Cosmic Egg (from Scivias) 


1. shaped like an egg: The twelfth century did not believe in a flat earth. The image of the cosmos as an egg is 
not original to Hildegard, but she was clearly fascinated by it. 

2. The horror... stones <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> and small: As Frances Beer suggests, ‘the vision is ultimately reassuring because it 
reveals how <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> can exist and, at the same <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> as it is part of the creation, be counterbalanced and controlled 
by the forces of good’. See her Women and Mystical Experience in the Middle Ages (Woodbridge, 1992), p. 46. 

3. between the north and the east... a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> mountain... towards the east: The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> mountain separates <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> in 
the east from <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> in the north. 

4. Through his creation... <span class="t20 hoverable">eternal</span> things: This is Hildegard’s explanation for her allegorical approach, namely 
that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">works</span> of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t9 t12 t15 t16 t17 t19 t22 t24 t25 t26 hoverable">creation</span> can be understood not only as phenomena of nature, but also as symbols illustrating 
the history of the faith. 

5. The elements... render them their service: The elements in medieval science are earth, air, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> (i.e. energy) 
and water; all are involved in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> physiology, and for Hildegard the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> being is seen as being at one with 
the world, as part of a positive <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> and ecology. 

6. ‘Thou <span class="t0 t6 t12 t13 t14 t15 t20 t22 t23 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">hast</span> crowned him... the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">works</span> ofthy hands’: From Psalm 8:5-6. 


21. The Cosmos (from Causes and Cures ) 


1. he was always <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> : See John 1:3-4. 

2. still unformed : Cf. Genesis 1:2: ‘And the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> form, and void; and darkness was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the face of 
the deep.’ 

3. ‘Let there be light’: Genesis 1:3. 

4. the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of the air which we can see: As in the vision of the cosmic egg in Scivias, the air forms a sublunary 
atmosphere, i.e. below the level of the moon’s orbit, while the ether is a higher, superlunary layer above the 
level of the moon. 

5. The fall of Lucifer: Many of the ideas in this <span class="t26 hoverable">passage</span> go back to the biblical verses on the same topic in Isaiah 
14:12-15. A similar <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span> of ideas about Lucifer occurs in The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of Life’s Merits VI, 14, treated there for their 
moral significance rather than as part of a cosmology, as here. 

6. his envy of God: As Margret Berger points out in her Hildegard of Bingen. On Natural Philosophy and 
Medicine (Cambridge, 1999), p. 24, this phrase could also be interpreted as ‘God’s punitive zeal’. Although such 
a phrase does not fit the context so well, it occurs in other writings of Hildegard, for instance in The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of 
Life’s Merits. 

7. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> every <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> being all <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">things</span> lie concealed: There are parallels to this idea in Erigena’s Periphyseon 
(755B) and Honorius of Autun’s Clavis physicae (n. 241); see Margret Berger, Hildegard of Bingen, p. 24. 

8. ancient counsel... man: Hildegard’s notion of the ‘ancient counsel’ indicates her belief in the ‘absolute 
predestination of Christ’, the doctrine that <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Christ</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> have become <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> <span class="t10 t12 t16 t20 t21 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whether</span> or not the Fall had <span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> 
place. 

9 .fire of judgement... stench and cold: In one of the plagues described in Exodus 9:23-4, hail falls during a 
thunderstorm, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> runs along the ground. In other words, there is the stench of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> mingled with the 
cold of the hail. 

10. the wings of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of God: Cf. Psalm 104:3. 

11. <span class="t4 t6 t7 t9 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 hoverable">bring</span> their song back into harmony: The Latin reads ‘cantum in symphoniaferent’, which connects this idea 
with Hildegard’s ‘Symphonia’, and the notion of heavenly harmony in her theology of music. 

12. bad humours... illness: According to the humoral physiology of ancient and medieval medicine, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> 
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> was made up of four humours in balance. According to the theory in its simplest terms, illness is caused 
either by an imbalance of humours or by bad humours. See Margret Berger, Hildegard of Bingen, p. 15. 

13. the sun’s heat is greater... above it: A <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> instance of the twelfth-century belief in a spherical earth, with the 
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> orbiting round it. In winter, according to this view, the other <span class="t6 hoverable">side</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> is warmer in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> to keep the 
temperature as a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> in balance. 

14. immoderation: Alack of balance. In the Hildegardian cosmos, everything must moderate itself to the mean. 

15. a loadstone attracting iron to it: The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">text</span> has ‘achates’, i.e. ‘agate’, the wrong kind of stone. There may have 
been a scribal error, with ‘achates’ being <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> instead of ‘magnes’; see Margret Berger, Hildegard of Bingen, p. 
29. 

16. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> precedes... the day... the moon precedes... the night... : The idea is adapted from Genesis 1:16-18: 
‘And <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> made <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> lights; the greater <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> to rule the day, and the lesser <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> to rule the night: he made 
the stars also. And <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span> them in the firmament of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heaven</span> to give <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the earth, and to rule over the 
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> and over the night, and to divide the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> from the darkness: and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> saw that it was good.’ See also Psalm 
136:8-9: ‘The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> to rule by day: for his mercy endureth for ever. The moon and stars to rule by night: for his 
mercy endureth for ever.’ 


22. Gemstones (from Physicci) 


l. [bewitched]... out of their mind: Compare this cure for enchantment with Hildegard’s parable condemning 
the <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> of the magic arts in Scivias I, 3 (see Introduction at II. 1). 


23. Songs from Symphonia 


1. 0 magne pater. Antiphon: See Barbara Newman (ed.), Hildegard of Bingen. Symphonia, 2nd edn (Ithaca, 
1998), no. 6. In her useful notes to this song, Newman suggests that it is influenced by Genesis 2:18. 

2. O eterne deus. Antiphon: Newman, Symphonia, no. 7. The song is based on the idea in Ephesians 1:22-3 that 
<span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Christ</span> is appointed to be <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">head</span> over the Church, which is his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> and limbs. This is then combined with an 
image of the first dawn derived from Psalm 110:3. 

3 . Ave Maria. Responsory: Newman, Symphonia, no. 8. 

4. O clarissima mater. Responsory: Newman, Symphonia, no. 9. The ‘star of the sea’ is a traditional image for 
Mary. 

5. O splendidissima gemma. Antiphon: Newman, Symphonia, no. 10. Adam of St Victor uses the same image of 
the gem in a sequence for Christmas. 

6. Hodie aperuit. Antiphon: Newman, Symphonia, no. 11. A song in which several very different images (gate, 
woman, dawn, flower) are presented in rapid succession. The idea of the ‘closed gate’ derives from a vision in 
Ezekiel 44:2-3 where the prophet sees a gate shut after the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> has passed through it and hears that ‘the prince 
himself is the only one who may sit inside the gateway to <span class="t28 hoverable">eat</span> in the presence of the Lord’. The serpent and the 
woman are from the story of Eve in the Garden of Eden. The Dendermonde manuscript begins the song with the 
very specific <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> ‘hodie’, ‘today’, rather than ‘ nunc ’, ‘now’, of other versions. 

7. Quia ergo femina. Antiphon: Newman, Symphonia, no. 12. Newman (p. 273) argues that the ‘ ergo ’ shows that 
this is a sequel to the preceding antiphon. The ‘form of a woman’ is both the Platonic idea and also a suggestion 
of weakness, as in the openings of Hildegard’s letters and visionary works. 

8. Cum processit factura. Antiphon: Newman, Symphonia, no. 13. There is a textual crux in the reading ‘joys of 
life’ Qgaudia vite) rather than ‘joys in you’ (‘g audio in te). 

9. O virga ac diadema. Sequence: Newman, Symphonia, no. 20. From an anecdote in the Canonization Protocol, 
there is evidence to suggest that this sequence was a particular favourite of Hildegard. See 35, paragraph 9.2 of 
the Protocol. 

10. Spiritus sanctus vivificans vita. Antiphon: Newman, Symphonia, no. 24. 

11. Caritas abundat. Antiphon: Newman, Symphonia, no. 25. An alternative medieval spelling of the title is 
Karitas habundat. 

12. O gloriosissimi. Antiphon: Newman, Symphonia, no. 29. 

13. O speculum columbe. Antiphon for John the Evangelist: Newman, Symphonia, no. 35. ‘The beloved <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">son</span> of 
the Lamb’ refers to the description ‘one of them, the disciple whom <span class="t0 t6 t8 t9 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t22 t23 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Jesus</span> loved’ in John 13:23. 

14. O dulcis electe. Responsory for John the Evangelist: Newman, Symphonia, no. 36. The phrase translated as 
‘on the greenness of the pastors of the Church’ (Latin ‘in viriditate pigmentariorum’) picks up the Hildegardian 
image of priests as ‘perfumers.’ 

15. O vis aeternitatis. Responsory: Newman, Symphonia, no. 1. The Dendermonde manuscript lacks a few pages 
at the beginning and it is possible that this song was the initial piece. See the journal article by Peter Dronke, 
‘The Composition of Hildegard of Bingen’s Symphonia’, Sacris Erudiri 19 (1969-70), pp. 381-93. 

16. O virtus sapientie: Newman, Symphonia, no. 2. For a discussion of the themes of this song see Introduction 
II.4. The ideas of the sapiential literature of the Apocrypha lie behind this text, particularly <span class="t12 t20 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">Wisdom</span> of Solomon 
8:1, which reads: ‘Wisdom reacheth from one end to another mightily: and sweetly doth she <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> all things’ and 
Ecclesiasticus 24:5-6, where <span class="t12 t20 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">Wisdom</span> speaks: ‘I alone compassed the circuit of heaven, and walked in the 
bottom of the deep. In the waves of the sea, and in all the earth, and in every <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> and nation, I got a 
possession.’ 


24. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Two</span> Christmas Homilies 


1. [ Pitra (ed., homilies Hi and Ilii ]: The Latin <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">text</span> <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> is from J. B. Pitra (ed.), Analecta sanctae Hildegardis 
opera , in Analecta Sacra, vol. 8 (Montecassino, 1882), pp. 247-9. 

2. For the first mass: This homily is intended to explain the Gospel reading for the first mass on Christmas Day. 

3. ancient counsel: The term <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> in Hildegard’s theology for the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> plan from before the creation. In giving 
allegorical meanings to the passage, Hildegard follows in the tradition of the commentaries of Bede and Gregory 
the Great, who see Caesar Augustus as representing God; but she adds a cosmological reading which is strongly 
influenced by Neoplatonism. See the detailed analysis in Peter Dronke, ‘Platonic-Christian Allegories in the 
Homilies of Hildegard of Bingen’, in Haijo Jan Westra (ed.), From Athens to Chartres. Neoplatonism and 
Medieval Thought. Studies in Honour of Edouard Teaunea (Leiden, 1992), pp. 281-96. 


25. The Iron Mountain (from Scivias) 


l. ‘He becometh poor... maketh rich’: Proverbs 10:4. 


26. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> Looking East and South (from The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of Life’s Merits ) 

1. And I saw...: Hildegard begins her vision appropriately with an opening formula that recalls the writings of 
the biblical prophets; cf. Ezekiel 1:4 or Revelation 5:1, 6, 11. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Note</span> also the alliteration of the /v/ consonants in 
the original Latin ‘Et vidi virum’. 

2. stood... turned... looked: Various important aspects of the Latin <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">text</span> do not come over in a modern English 
translation: in this paragraph, there is the end rhyme ‘-bat’, ‘-at’ on the last <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> verbs, as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as a rhythmical 
balance and cadence: ‘supra abyssum stabat. Et se ad orientem verterat, ita quod et orientem et austrum 
inspiciebat’ . Such acoustic and rhetorical features were calculated to please the medieval reader, who more often 
than not listened to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">text</span> being read aloud, or murmured it quietly during the act of reading. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span> 
Hildegard’s Latin may not be conventional by the classical standards of the ‘twelfth-century Renaissance’ (and 
her secretary Volmar may in <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> have edited and corrected her Latin case-endings and conjugations), 
nevertheless she is clearly in <span class="t5 hoverable">full</span> control of both her content and her medium of its expression. 

3. writing tablet: The Latin tabula is here translated as ‘writing tablet’. Parchment was expensive and paper 
unavailable in this period. The essential note-taking tool since Roman times had been a wooden frame filled 
with wax that was <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> in conjunction with a metal writing stylus; the writing on the soft wax could be erased 
and the <span class="t4 t9 t12 t24 t26 hoverable">tablet</span> reused. In the opening illustration of the Rupertsberg codex of Scivias (and in many of the 
illustrations of the Lucca manuscript of The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span> Works), the figure of Hildegard is depicted in the act 
of receiving the vision and writing it down on her tablet; only her secretary (Volmar) is seen actually using pen, 
ink and parchment. 

4. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of God: <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Note</span> here also the characteristic Hildegardian theological term ‘scientia Dei ’, ‘knowledge 
of God’. 

5. one sound: By repetition of the adjective ‘one’, Hildegard rings the changes on the concept of unity: ‘one life... 
one will... one conjunction... one devotion... one sound’ (Latin ‘uno sono’). The latter phrase has been translated 
‘with one sound’, but Hildegard must mean that the ‘host of <span class="t11 hoverable">blessed</span> spirits’ blend their voices to sing in unison, 
a type of musical experience with which she was very familiar from her own songs and settings for the liturgy. 
The notion of the ‘sound’ of all varieties of music occurs in the letter to Bernard of Clairvaux (i). 

6. aforementioned: The frequent adjective ‘aforementioned’ or ‘aforesaid’ (' praedictus 0 is strange to modern 
ears, but serves to orient the medieval audience and prompt their memories as they listen to the reading of the 
text. 

7. trumpet blast... habitations: Hildegard’s vocabulary is heavily influenced by that of Revelation, Ezekiel and 
other apocalyptic and visionary writings. Cf. Revelation 8:12-13. 

8. lion... goat: The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> for ‘lion’ and ‘goat’ are leo and capricornus, both signs of the zodiac; they are referred 
to here not necessarily for any astrological <span class="t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> but rather for their astronomical and symbolic significance. 
The twelve signs of the zodiac are, it will be recalled, positions <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the belt of stars in the night sky against 
which observers can plot the changing position of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> at the various times of the year. 

9. the ‘misleader’: The Latin for ‘leader’, dux, is derived from the same root <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> duco, ‘I lead’, as seductor, 
hence the translation ‘misleader’. Hildegard is using etymology to emphasize her point. 

10. a cloud coming from the North: The North is the region of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> associated with the devil; the cloud that 
originates there is described as ‘aridus’, an apt choice of adjective to represent <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> and a term which in 
Hilldegard’s <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">works</span> contrasts effectively with her important and frequently encountered notion of ‘viriditas’, or 
‘greenness’, as <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> for instance in this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">text</span> in Mercy’s speech against the fourth figure, Hardness of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Heart</span> (see 
The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of Life’s Merits I, 8). 

11. ancient serpent: The ‘serpent’ is of course the devil, as in the <span class="t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of the Fall in the biblical Genesis. 
‘Ancient Enemy’ (‘ antiquus hostis’) is a traditional term for the devil in medieval literature, with origins in 
patristic commentaries and sermons. 

12. the images... of vices: Here, as also in her exegesis, Hildegard stresses the symbolic <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of her vision; she 
sees symbolic images of vices rather than actual creatures, and among the forms she sees, she chooses to focus 


on seven 



27. The Seven Vices and Virtues (from The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of Life’s Merits ) 

1. The Wonders of the East: See Richard Stoneman, Legends of Alexander the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Great</span> (London, 1994), pp. 20-24. 

2. So why dry up... for shame!: The Latin style is worthy of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">note</span> in this passage. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span> not a poem as such, it 
is remarkable for its strong rhythms and the AB AB AAA rhyme-scheme of its verbs, as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as other internal 
rhymes in -um; <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">note</span> also the alliteration on the [k] sounds as represented by the letters <c> and <q>: 

Et quare arescerem, cum omnem viriditatem habeam? Cur quasi in senili etate viverem, cum in iuventute 
floream? Quare pulchrum visum oculorum in cecitate ducerem? Quod si hocfacerem, erubescerem.’ 

[‘So why dry up when I possess all <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of greenness? Why live in senile old age, when I can flourish in 
youthfulness? Why keep in the dark the beautiful vision of the eyes? If I did that, I <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> blush for shame!’] 

The language seems to echo and reinforce to the semi-aggressive statements of amor seculi. With an 
unmistakable and distinct voice, <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t8 t13 t15 t17 t18 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">Love</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">World</span> is characterized here as a kind of elemental wild man, 
speaking about positive forces such as ‘greenness’ but misusing them - in Hildegard’s <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> - for false purposes. 
This feature of a vice using the language of virtue to deceive her audience is also found in Prudentius’s 
Psychomachia. 

3. 1 <span class="t13 t14 t15 t18 t27 hoverable">heard</span> a <span class="t23 hoverable">voice</span> respond to the first figure: The <span class="t23 hoverable">voice</span> of the first virtue, ‘Heavenly Love’. 

4. The <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> figure... prey: The dog Hildegard depicts here appears to be a kind of coursing-hound or hunting- 
dog. As emerges in the later exegesis which follows the narrative of the vices, the <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> figure represents 
petulantia, which could be translated as ‘Fickleness’, since the vice is described as chasing after whims and 
deceiving <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> with fine talk about laughter. The Latin <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> also has connotations of ‘impudence’, a 
personality feature which also emerges - at least in part - in the characterization of the figure here, for instance 
in the <span class="t24 hoverable">fact</span> that the vice entices <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> then deals them serious wounds. 

5. 1 <span class="t13 t14 t15 t18 t27 hoverable">heard</span> a voice: As we learn later in the book, the virtue ‘True Discipline’ is speaking here. 

6. The <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> figure... clothing: The <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> vice represents ioculatrix, ‘Superficiality’, ‘Jocularity’ or ‘Amusemen’, a 
kind of superficial lack of gravity which the <span class="t23 hoverable">voice</span> from the cloud condemns as ‘idolatry’. As with the other vices 
that employ the vocabulary of virtue to beautify their own speeches and actions, Superficiality attempts to make 
himself attractive to his listeners by evoking the joy of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heaven</span> and using this to justify his own behaviour. 

7. the response of the <span class="t23 hoverable">voice</span> from the storm-cloud: Spoken by the virtue ‘Shame’. 

8. The fourth figure... motionless: The fourth image, the cloud of smoke, represents obduratio, Hardness of 
Heart’. 

9. So why should I labour... to pieces?: <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Note</span> the rhyming prose in the original Latin (lines 194-5): ‘Quare ergo 
causa ullius laborarem, et me dilacerarem?’ (‘Why should I labour for any <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> cause? Why tear myself to 
pieces?’). 

10. the <span class="t23 hoverable">voice</span> from the aforementioned storm-cloud: The fourth virtue is ‘True Mercy’. 

11. the stone presents its moisture: The idea of ‘perspiration’ in stones is explicable as part of the medieval 
notion of the four elements, namely: <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> (i.e. solid matter), air (gases), <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> (energy) and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> (moisture), 
each of which is found in varying quantities in every <span class="t16 hoverable">created</span> thing. See The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of Gemstones in 22. 

12. The fifth figure... <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> head: The fifth vice is ignavia, ‘Lack of Spirit’. This figure with a large ear covering 
all its <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">head</span> is reminiscent of creatures with grotesquely exaggerated limbs in the Marvels of the East tradition. 

13. the response of the <span class="t23 hoverable">voice</span> from the storm-cloud: The fifth virtue is ‘Divine Victory’. 

14. The sixth figure... burning brands: The sixth vice, ira, ‘Anger’, has flames issuing from its mouth like the 
monsters of legend, while the firebrands recall depictions of Anger in the traditional illustrations of vices in 
manuscripts of Prudentius’s Psychomachia. 

15. the response ofthe <span class="t23 hoverable">voice</span> from the storm-cloud: The sixth virtue is ‘Divine Patience’; patience is the 
traditional remedy for anger in the psychomachia tradition. 

16. The seventh figure... quite naked: The seventh vice is inepta letitia, ‘Foolish Joy’. Similarities will be noted 


between the individual members of this group of seven sins; here in particular Foolish Joy recalls the first, 
<span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> and <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> figures of vice, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> also follows on from the preceding figure ‘Anger’, as Hildegard explains 
later, ‘because when a <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> shows joy after being angry, he humiliates his enemies, who feel the insults 
heaped <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> them all the more strongly when they see him happy’. 

17. the response of the <span class="t23 hoverable">voice</span> from the storm-cloud: The seventh virtue is ‘Desire for God’. 


28. The <span class="t23 hoverable">Voice</span> from <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Heaven</span> (from The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of Life’s Merits ) 


1. black schism : Possibly a reference to the eighteen-year schism between Pope Alexander <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span> and Emperor 
Frederick Barbarossa which began in 1159, shortly after Hildegard had started <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> on The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of Life’s Merits. 

2. man... lion... ox... eagle... four: The four images of the man, the lion, the bull and the eagle from Ezekiel 1:10 
were traditionally interpreted as symbols of the four evangelists, for instance in the iconography of the 
illuminated gospel books of the early Middle Ages. In Hildegard these become theological symbols, each using 
traditional animal imagery to illustrate aspects of God: his goodness, power, sacrifice, and knowledge. 

3. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of the activity of God. ..from God: The same idea is basic to the <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> of the trilogy, The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> 
of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span> Works. 

4. For he alone knows all things... grace: Hildegard has a strong <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t17 t19 t25 t26 hoverable">sense</span> of immanence, that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> is present and 
actively at <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> in the world. 

5. ‘The Lord... his enemies’: Isaiah 42:13. Hildegard has <span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> the image of the ‘mighty man’ from Isaiah and 
adapted it to her own vision, as she explains in the following paragraphs. 

6. Before the ancient days... destruction: A contrast is made between the heights of the Lord’s <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> - as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> to 
the living - and the carelessness of Pride ‘who attempts to climb before he has seen the ladder’. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Note</span> also in this 
<span class="t26 hoverable">passage</span> the key concept of the ‘ancient counsel’ or plan that has been prepared beforehand against the forces of 
pride. 

7. But he prepared his quiver and arrows... <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> of war: This is the traditional patristic image of the devil as an 
archer (Psalm 11:2 in the Authorized Version), here attempting to have his revenge for the fall from heaven. 

8. He then <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> up ‘the Word... never cease: The idea that ‘the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> shall go forth as a mighty man’ is linked now 
to the incarnation of Christ, when ‘the Word... became flesh’ (John 1:14). The battle with the enemy is seen as 
one of active <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> against idle and inactive evil, and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">text</span> becomes a prophecy of the apocalypse. 

9. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> is of such stature’... and no end: At this point Hildegard returns to the details of the opening vision 
and explains them step by step, beginning with some reflections for the reader on how the eternity of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> is to 
be understood. 

10. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> is eternal... a flaming <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> in judgement: By a series of associated images Hildegard connects eternity 
with fire, God’s power, rational thought, the senses, and judgement. A key influence is Psalm 104, the <span class="t4 hoverable">hymn</span> to 
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t9 t12 t15 t16 t17 t19 t22 t24 t25 t26 hoverable">creation</span> and renewal from the Psalms, especially the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">verse</span> ‘Who maketh... his ministers a flaming fire’ (Psalm 
104: 4; Authorized Version). 

11. Before the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> of the Law... any other kind of law: The figure of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> in the original vision is now 
employed allegorically for a discussion of salvation history and the purgation of sin. In the allegory, the 
shoulders of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> represent the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">law</span> of Moses, as in the biblical <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">verse</span> Hildegard is about to discuss in 
paragraph 26, ‘the government shall be <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> his shoulder’ (Isaiah 9:6). 

12. on the shoulder of his strength: Hildegard’s style here is extremely allusive and associative, but the main 
message seems to be that the shoulder is a symbol for the strength and justice of Christ. 

13. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> the venomous seed of a man: The doctrine of the ‘venomous seed of a man’ contrasts with more 
positive views of sexuality, for instance in Hildegard’s Causes and Cures. 

14. the Old <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Law</span> was the sound and shadow of the word... <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Christ</span> , then appeared: Hildegard shows some 
acquaintance with reflections on language, in particular the difference between a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> as an abstract meaning- 
bearing entity and the spoken <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> as a sound perceived by the senses and subject to the limitations of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> and 
space. Hildegard’s source, however, remains unclear, for unlike many early medieval writers she does not cite 
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> passages from her authorities. Ultimately, the influence of Augustine is apparent, for instance his 
musings on time, speech, memory and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Word</span> in Books X and XI of his Confessions. In a relevant <span class="t26 hoverable">passage</span> in 
<span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> XI, <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">chapter</span> 6 translated by Pine-Coffin (Harmondsworth, 1961, p. 258), Augustine addresses <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> as 
follows: 

But how did you speak? Did you <span class="t9 t11 t20 t21 t22 t23 t27 hoverable">speak</span> as you did when your <span class="t23 hoverable">voice</span> was <span class="t13 t14 t15 t18 t27 hoverable">heard</span> in the clouds saying: This is my 


beloved Son? At that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> your <span class="t23 hoverable">voice</span> sounded and then ceased. It was speech with a beginning and an end. Each 
syllable could be <span class="t13 t14 t15 t18 t27 hoverable">heard</span> and then died away, the <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> following after the first and the <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> after the second, 
and so on in sequence until the last syllable followed all the rest and then gave <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> to silence. [...] These 
words, which you had caused to sound in time, were reported by the bodily ear of the hearer to the mind, which 
has <span class="t14 t24 hoverable">intelligence</span> and inward hearing responsive to your <span class="t20 hoverable">eternal</span> Word. 

15. the sound and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> came together... in agreement: By contrast to the Old Testament, under the New 
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Law</span> the sound and <span class="t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t19 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> become inseparable, a theme touched on further below. 

16. the Old <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Law</span> was in shadow... anything different: An analogy is made between the shadowy <span class="t11 t16 hoverable">existence</span> in the 
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Law</span> of the Old Testament period and the shadowy <span class="t11 t16 hoverable">existence</span> of the souls of the saints awaiting the resurrection 
of the body. 

17. From his knees to the calves of his legs he is in the earth.’... their sustenance: Hildegard draws an analogy 
between the supporting knees of the cosmic <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> and the sustaining strength of the earth, both of which can 
flex under pressure and then return afterwards to their ‘rightful condition’. 

18. So also the Church... endure invincible: Having <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span> up the image of the flexible knees, Hildegard now applies 
it on a prophetic level to the ‘New Nation’, that is the Church, which will come under pressure during the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> 
of the Antichrist and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> in the end endure invincible. 

19. She will stand firmly on her feet: Just as the cosmic <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> ‘rests in his mysteries’, so the Church in the last 
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 hoverable">days</span> will ‘stand firmly on her feet’. 

20. ‘Who <span class="t0 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">hath</span> measured... depth of the abyss?’ : From the Old Testament Apocrypha - the <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> of <span class="t12 t20 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">wisdom</span> 
literature known as Ecclesiasticus (or Sirach) 1:3. 

21. It was Wisdom... penetrated the abyss: In Ecclesiasticus 24:5, <span class="t12 t20 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">Wisdom</span> speaks: ‘I alone compassed the 
circuit of heaven, and walked in the bottom of the deep.’ 

22. your ways are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> and just: See Revelation 16:7. In the <span class="t26 hoverable">passage</span> following, the biblical quotation is 
expanded into a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> prayer spoken on behalf of erring humanity who need to realize the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">truth</span> that the Lord’s 
‘judgements are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> and just’. 

23. the mountain, which is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of God: The image of the mountain as the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> can be 
compared with the mountain in Scivias 1 , 1 (25), or in the description of the cosmic egg in Scivias I, 3 (20), or in 
the letters to Henry, Bishop of Liege or Prior Dimo (14, 30). 

24. ‘He <span class="t13 t14 t15 t18 t27 hoverable">heard</span> hidden words, which it is not permitted for anyone to speak’: II Corinthians 12:4. Hildegard at no 
point states clearly that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> ‘caught up into paradise’ in this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">verse</span> refers to the Apostle Paul, which is the 
traditional <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> of this passage. Instead, Hildegard expands on the notion of ‘hidden words’ that are revealed to 
visionaries, as in her own case, and it is tempting to relate this <span class="t26 hoverable">passage</span> to her short treatise on the ‘unknown 
language’ which she wrote in the 1150s before starting on The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of Life’s Merits. 


29. The Unknown Language 

1. examples... of interest: <span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">Taken</span> from Jean-Baptiste Pitra (ed.), Sanctae Hildegardis opera, in Analecta sacra, 
vol. 8 (Montecassino, 1882), p. 497. 

2. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> formation: The root aieg seems to be important, as do the endings -nz and -iz. Other examples not 
listed above suggest influence from Latin or German, e.g. vanix, ‘woman’, perhaps from Latin vanitas, ‘vanity’, 
falschin, ‘poet’, perhaps from Middle <span class="t23 hoverable">High</span> German valsch, ‘false’, and sonziz, ‘apostle’, possibly related to the 
sonus or ‘sacred sound’ to which Hildegard frequently referred. For more information on Hildegard’s language, 
see Marie-Louise Portmann and Alois Odermatt (eds), Worterbuch der unbekannten Sprache [Dictionary of the 
Unknown Language] (Basel, 1986). 

3. See <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">note</span> 24 to 28. 

4. The original text... English translation: Pudentiana Barth and Immaculata Ritscher (eds), Hildegard von 
Bingen. Lieder (Salzburg, 1969), no. 67 and Barbara Newman (ed.), Hildegard of Bingen. Symphonia, 2nd edn 
(Ithaca, 1998), no. 68; for a discussion of the song, see Newman, Symphonia, pp. 316-17. 


30. Allegorical Letters 


1. Abbess ofAltena...: See 32, Letter 49 for the abbess’s bid for friendship. 

2. abbess and teacher : Latin ‘magistra’. 

3. ‘Behold, the lion... prevailed ’: Revelation 5:5. 

4. into the abyss: II Peter 2:4. 

5. With rending teeth he drives all injustice from him: Cf. Psalm 34:16 (Vulgate) or Psalm 35:16 (Authorized 
Version). 

6. Eberhard, Archbishop of Salzburg...: See Eberhard’s letter to Hildegard (32, Letter 25). 

7. ‘You are gods... <span class="t0 t2 t3 t6 t7 t13 t14 t15 t20 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">sons</span> of the most High’: Psalm 81:6 (Vulgate) or 82:6 (Authorized Version); the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">verse</span> is 
referred to by <span class="t0 t6 t8 t9 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t22 t23 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Jesus</span> in John 10:34. 

8. the circuit of the heaven: Ecclesiasticus 24:5. 

9. <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t8 t13 t15 t17 t18 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">Love</span> is my matter: Hildegard’s idea of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t9 t12 t15 t16 t17 t19 t22 t24 t25 t26 hoverable">creation</span> from ‘matter’, or material, includes the idea of the maternal, 
i.e. the image of the mother bearing a child. 

10. he who is: Exodus 3:14. 

11. Adam ofEbrach... : For Adam’s letter to Hildegard, see 32, Letter 85. 

12. she had in her right hand... moon: Cf. Revelation 1:16. 

13. 1 begot thee: Psalm 109:3 (Vulgate). This differs from the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">text</span> of the Authorized Version (Psalm 110:3). 

14. Love: In the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t17 t19 t25 t26 hoverable">sense</span> of charity, Latin caritas. 

15. base matter: Latin ‘materia’, with connotations of mater, ‘mother’. 

16. ‘Let it be done’: Latin fiat’, as in Genesis 1:3, ‘Let there be light’. 

17. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Lord</span> said... at my right hand’: Psalm 109:1 (Vulgate) or 110:1 (Authorized Version). 

18. the ancient of days: Daniel 7:9. 

19. ‘Increase... fill the earth’: Genesis 1:28. 

20. Humility redeemed him: There is a strong association between the earth, humility and humanity in writings 
on this theme. 

21. the eye of love... heavenly love: Latin ‘caritas’ and ‘amor’ respectively. 

22. <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t8 t13 t15 t17 t18 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">Love</span> and Humility: The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">text</span> has <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t8 t13 t15 t17 t18 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">Love</span> and Obedience knocking at the door, but this may be an error. The 
allegory makes better <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t17 t19 t25 t26 hoverable">sense</span> if the knight Obedience is sitting in the house, and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> maidens <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t8 t13 t15 t17 t18 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">Love</span> and 
Humility are at the door. 

23. you will never be... confounded: Latin: ‘nee morte morieris’. 


31. A Vision of <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t8 t13 t15 t17 t18 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">Love</span> (from The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">Works</span> ) 


l. ‘Fiat, let there be...’: From the Vulgate <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">text</span> of Genesis 1:3. 


32. Queries and Requests: Selected Letters to Hildegard 


1. correspondents: Further information on the recipients and personalities involved is given in the Glossary. For 
convenience, the letters selected have been numbered according to the edition by Lieven Van Acker, Hildegardis 
Bingensis Epistolarium CCCM 9i-9ia (Turnhout,i99i and 1993) and the translation by Joseph L. Baird and 
Radd K. Ehrman, The Letters of Hildegard of Bingen, 2 vols (Oxford, 1994 and 1998). Van Acker’s arrangement 
follows the hierarchical ranking of the letters as preserved in the major manuscript collection, rather than the 
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> in which they were written. Since many of the letters cannot be dated precisely, the chronological <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> 
attempted in this selection should be seen as only approximate. 

2. Bernard of Clairvaux...: For Hildegard’s request for support, see 1, Letter 1. 

3. ‘God opposes... the humble’: Proverbs 3:34, quoted in James 4:6 and I Peter 5:5. 

4. Odo ofSoissons...: For Hildegard’s reply, see 4. 

5. ‘The king... chamber’: Song of Songs 1:4. 

6. my secret to myself: Isaiah 24:16 (Vulgate text). 

7. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Hezekiah... angered the Lord: See Isaiah 39:2-8. Odo is using the example of Hezekiah to warn 
Hildegard against the dangers of revealing <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> treasures to opponents. 

8. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> certain <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">things</span> under a seal: A <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> is placed under a seal in Revelation 5:1. The idea is common also in 
Hildegard’s writings. 

9. ‘the woman thatfeareth the Lord, she shall be praise’: Proverbs 31:30. 

10. the melodies of a new song: The allusion to Hildegard’s compositions shows that she was already writing 
songs by the late 1140s. 

11. many scholars argue that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> is not identical with both paternity and divinity: This was one of the theses 
of Gilbert Porreta, Bishop of Poitiers. 

12. Heinrich, Archbishop of Mainz...: For Hildegard’s aggressive reply, see 12. 

13. a sister... in your monastery: The reference is to Richardis of Stade. 

14. Henry, Bishop of Liege...: For Hildegard’s reply, see 14. 

15. Arnold, Archbishop of Cologne...: Hildegard’s short reply is quoted in the introduction to 16. 

16. the book... interference: A reference to Scivias, probably the most widely known of Hildegard’s books during 
her lifetime. 

17. Gertrud ( ofStahleck )...: Hildegard sent an encouraging response; see 18. 

18. ‘things... <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heart</span> of man’: I Corinthians 2:9. 

19. the wine of sorrow : I follow here the translation by Baird and Ehrman, in The Letters, vol. 1. 

20. the one whom I desire: Song of Songs 2:3: ‘As the apple tree among the trees of the woods, so is my beloved 
among the sons. I sat down under his shadow whom I desired: and his fruit was sweet to my palate.’ 

21 .Abbess of... Bamberg...: For Hildegard’s reply see 19. 

22. An Abbess ofAltena...: Hildegard’s response is allegorical and does not quite match the personal tone of the 
abbess’s letter; see 30, Letter 49R. 

23. sitting with Mary at the feet of Christ: Probably a reference to Mary Magdalene (see Matthew 27:61); the 
imagery of <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Christ</span> the beloved derives from interpretations of the Song of Songs. 

24. secret chamber of your heart: Perhaps a reference to the story of Judith in the Old Testament Apocrypha. 
See, for instance, Judith 8:5 in the <span class="t28 hoverable">Jerusalem</span> Bible. 

25. tasted... sweet: Psalm 34:8. 

26. face to face: I Corinthians 13:12. 

27. Eberhard, Archbishop of Salzburg...: For the allegory Hildegard wrote in response, see 30, Letter 25R. 

28. you will enter... heavenly bridegroom: An allusion to the parable of the Five <span class="t8 t12 t17 hoverable">Wise</span> Virgins, who bought oil 
for their lamps so that when the bridegroom came they were ready, and ‘they <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">went</span> in with him to the marriage’, 


while the five foolish virgins remained outside, with no oil for their lamps. See Matthew 25:1-12. 

29. the Emperor’s court at Mainz: Emperor Frederick Barbarossa held royal audiences at various intervals in 
different locations throughout the empire. This occasion, in 1163, was particularly important for Hildegard 
because she received an imperial deed of protection for the Rupertsberg convent. Eberhard’s name appears 
among the many names of witnesses to the deed, which also include Archbishop Conrad of Mainz, Archbishop 
Eberhard of Bamberg and Bishop Henry of Liege. 

30. under a seal: Eberhard wants a sealed letter in reply for extra security. He himself was in a difficult political 
situation: as a friend of the Emperor, he nevertheless supported Pope Alexander <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span> against the antipope Victor 
IV. 

31 .Abbot Adam...: Adam’s letter provoked a fascinating letter in reply; see 30, Letter 85R/A. 

32. rejoiced with a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> joy : The wording is biblical. Cf. Matthew 2:10: ‘And seeing the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> star, they rejoiced 
with exceeding <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> joy.’ 

33. allow your <span class="t23 hoverable">voice</span> to be <span class="t13 t14 t15 t18 t27 hoverable">heard</span> in our land: A reference to Hildegard’s first preaching tour, between 1158 and 
1161. 


33* From The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Life</span> ofHildegard, <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> 2 , by Theoderich of Echternach 

1. She revealed certain <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">things</span> about the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> being... such things: A reference to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> now 
known as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> separate books: Causes and Cures and Physica. 

2. in marvellous harmony : The Latin <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> is ‘symphonia’, the same <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> occurring in the title of 
Hildegard’s collected songs, The Symphony of the Harmony of Celestial Relations. 

3. other typological expositions: This refers to Hildegard’s commentaries on the Creed and the Benedictine 
Rule. 

4. key of David... no <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> openeth ’: Revelation 3:7. 

5. ‘the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> <span class="t0 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">hath</span> <span class="t0 t4 t6 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t19 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">brought</span> her to his storerooms’: See Song of Songs 1:3 (Douay-Rheims translation following the 
Latin Vulgate) or Song of Songs 1:4 (Authorized Version). 

6. ‘inebriated with the plenty of his house’: See Psalm 35:9 (Vulgate), or the slightly different <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">text</span> in the 
Authorized Version (Psalm 36:8). 

7. she will conceive... over the earth: Cf. Isaiah 26:18. 

8. as her fellow initiate: Here Volmar, Hildegard’s secretary, is referred to as a ‘symmista’, i.e. someone else who 
had been initiated into heavenly mysteries.
