9. he who has the file... <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> ears’: Volmar’s <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> as a scribe is here described with the conventional image of 
the grammarian as a craftsman who files down the rough metal and so polishes the style of the Latin. 

10. ‘My beloved... of my being’: Song of Songs 5:4 (cf. the <span class="t1 t2 t5 t10 t25 hoverable">texts</span> of the Vulgate and <span class="t28 hoverable">Jerusalem</span> Bible). This same 
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">text</span> was also <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> by Rupert of Deutz to justify his own visionary experiences. 

11. 1 was offered to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> for the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> life: Hildegard joins Jutta, either at her household or at the anchorage. 


34* Gebeno of Eberbach: The Pentachronon 


1. Gebeno... Hildegard’s letter: Since the Pentachronon is unpublished, information on Gebeno’s selections is 
printed only in Jean Baptiste Pitra (ed.) , Analecta sanctae Hildegardis opera spicilegio solesme parata, in the 
series Analecta sacra, vol. <span class="t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t10 t12 t17 t21 t25 t26 hoverable">VIII</span> (Montecassino, 1882), pp. 483-8. 

2. [Conrad <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span> to Hildegard J: The <span class="t1 t2 t5 t10 t25 hoverable">texts</span> of this letter and Hildegard’s reply are printed in PL 97, 185A-186B. 

3. my son... succeed me: In the end Conrad nominated his nephew, Frederick Barbarossa, to succeed him in 
1152. 


35* From the Canonization Protocol 


l .Abbess of Rupertsberg: The official title of the abbess is magistra (mistress), as it was in Hildegard’s time. 

2. Seguwize... Hildegard: The story of how Seguwize was eventually healed of demon possession is told in the 
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Life</span> of Hildegard, <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> 3, 20-22. 

3. tertian or quartan fever: A tertian is the kind of fever that recurs every other <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> (by inclusive reckoning 
every <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> day, hence the name tertian). A quartan is a fever that recurs, by inclusive reckoning, every fourth 
day. For information on medieval views of the causes of such fevers, see the introduction to Margret Berger, 
Hildegard of Bingen. On Natural Philosophy and Medicine (Cambridge, 1999), p. 16. 

4. The more reasonable part: The Latin has ‘sanior’, here translated ‘more reasonable’. 

5. O virga ac diadema : ‘O branch and diadem’, one of Hildegard’s sequences dedicated to Saint Mary. 

6. all the masters... theology: A reference to the lecturers of the schools of Paris, which at this stage were 
developing into the medieval university of Paris. 

7. twelve books: The twelve ‘books’ could be the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> parts of Scivias, the six parts of The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of Life’s Merits 
and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> of The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span> Works. 

8. William of Auxerre... : The mention of William of Auxerre, who became a <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">master</span> at Paris in about 1210 and 
died in Rome perhaps in 1231, helps to give an approximate date to the events recorded here. 


GLOSSARY 


ABELARD, PETER (c. 1079-c. 1142) Brilliant and controversial logician and theologian of twelfth-century 
France, the celebrated lover of Heloise and enemy of Bernard of Clairvaux. 

ADAM OF EBRACH First Abbot of the Cistercian monastery of Ebrach (founded in 1127), between Kitzingen 
and Bamberg in the Main region. Originally a monk at Morimond, Adam had assisted his friend Bernard of 
Clairvaux in preaching the Crusade in 1147, and in 1152 he was sent by Barbarossa as an envoy to Pope 
Eugenius III. He met Hildegard during her first preaching tour, between 1158 and 1161. 

ADELHEID OF GANDERSHEIM (d. 1184) Nun and abbess. <span class="t0 t4 t6 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t19 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Brought</span> up in the same household as her young 
aunt Richardis of Stade, she also joined Hildegard’s convent but <span class="t3 t13 t18 t24 hoverable">left</span> in 1151 to become Abbess of 
Gandersheim in eastern Germany. In 1160 she also acquired a similar position as <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">head</span> of a community of 
canons at Quedlinburg. 

/EL RED OF RIEVAULX (1109-67) Cistercian abbot from Rievaulx, North Yorkshire. Author of The Mirror of 
<span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t8 t13 t15 t17 t18 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">Love</span> (1142-3), <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> at the instigation of Bernard of Clairvaux, and On <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">Spiritual</span> Friendship (1150-65), a 
classic expression of monastic friendship. 

ALAN OF LILLE (d. 1203) Poet and theologian. Probably studied and taught at Paris, c. 1150-c. 1185. Influenced 
by Gilbert Porreta. Among his literary <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">works</span> are the Plaint of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Nature</span> in prose and verse, in which the main 
character is the personified figure of Nature, and the allegorical poem Anticlaudianus (1182-3). 

ALCUIN OF YORK (c. 740-804) A major scholar, teacher and writer at the court of Charlemagne. In his biblical 
scholarship, he promoted the Vulgate text, which came to be accepted as the standard version of the Bible in 
the medieval West. 

ALEXANDER III, POPE (d. 1181) Orlando (or Rolandus) Bandinelli. Papal chancellor under Eugenius III, he 
was elected Pope in 1159 on the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> of Hadrian IV, and immediately faced a rival antipope Victor IV 
elected by the supporters of Emperor Frederick Barbarossa. Throughout the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> schism with the Emperor, 
Alexander <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span> lived mostly in France, and nurtured contacts with Henry II, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> of England, whom he forced 
to do penance after the murder of Thomas Becket. Alexander presided over the <span class="t7 hoverable">Third</span> Lateran Council in 
1179, which gave the exclusive right of electing a pope to a two-thirds majority of the cardinals. 

AMBROSIUS AUTPERTUS (d. 784) Writer and theologian. <span class="t16 t24 hoverable">Born</span> in Provence, he became a monk of St Vincent 
near Capua in Italy c. 740 and was elected Abbot in 777. His main <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> is a commentary on Revelation, but 
he also wrote the Conflict of the Vices and Virtues, which appears to have influenced Hildegard’s <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of 
Life’s Merits. 

ARNOLD OF BRESCIA A native of Brescia in Lombardy and a fiery reformer. Unlike Hildegard, he encouraged 
lay <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> not to accept the sacraments from priests guilty of simony; he also preached the disendowment of 
pope and clergy. As supporter and then leader of the Roman Senate, he drove out Pope Eugenius <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span> from 
Rome and was excommunicated in 1148. In 1152 the Senate lost control of Rome, and Arnold was finally 
overthrown and hanged in 1155 during the pontificate of Pope Hadrian IV. 

ARNOLD, ARCHBISHOP OF COLOGNE Archbishop of Cologne before Rainald of Dassel, Arnold wrote to 
Hildegard requesting a copy of Scivias (see 32 and, for Hildegard’s response, 16). 

ARNOLD, ARCHBISHOP OF MAINZ (Served as Archbishop 1153-60) <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Well</span> regarded by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Conrad III, he was 
elected Archbishop of Mainz at Frederick Barbarossa’s instigation. In 1158 Arnold issued <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> charters 
confirming the agreement Hildegard had made with the Disibodenberg to secure the property rights and 
income of the Rupertsberg and to arrange for priests to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> services and perform other clerical duties for 
the community. During his period in office, he came into conflict with the Count Palatine Hermann of 
Stahleck and also had problems raising the tribute for Barbarossa’s Italian expeditions. On 1 November 1159 
he placed the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">city</span> of Mainz under excommunication before joining Barbarossa in Italy. On his return 
the dispute worsened and Arnold was killed during the violence that followed. 



AUGUSTINE OF HIPPO (354-430) St Augustine, Bishop of Hippo in North Africa, is probably the most famous 
of the four ‘Doctors of the Church’. His influence was enormous, and his numerous <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">works</span> include 
Confessions, On the Trinity, Christian Teaching, The Catechism of the Unlearned as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as numerous other 
treatises and sermons. 

BASSUM Monastery in the diocese of Bremen where Richardis of Stade was appointed Abbess. 

BENEDICTINE <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">ORDER</span> The traditional Western European monasticism, founded by St Benedict of Nursia (c. 
480-c. 550); Benedict’s Rule for Monasteries regulated the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span> Office (Latin opus Dei), the daily pattern 
of worship and prayer divided into eight ‘offices’: matins at the end of the night, lauds at daybreak, prime, 
terce, sext and none during the day, vespers in the evening, and compline at sunset. The offices during the 
hours of daylight were interspersed with periods of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> and reading. Hildegard wrote a commentary on the 
Rule, probably in the period 1151-8. 

BERNARD OF CHARTRES (c. 1080-c. 1130) From c. 1114, <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">master</span> of the famous cathedral school of Chartres. 
According to one of his pupils, John of Salisbury, Bernard revered the arts and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of ancient Greece 
and Rome which he saw as far exceeding that of his own day; for Bernard, his contemporaries were ‘dwarfs, 
standing on the shoulders of the giants’. 

BERNARD OF CLAIRVAUX (1090-1153) <span class="t16 t24 hoverable">Born</span> in Burgundy, Bernard of Fontaines became famous under the 
name of the Cistercian monastery he founded in 1115 and ruled as abbot until his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> in 1153. The most 
important Cistercian of his time, he wrote numerous works, including letters, sermons, satirical <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">works</span> and 
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> writings. An ascetic in his early years, Bernard became more politically involved after 1128, 
intervening in disputes between important figures in the Church. In 1140 his influence led to the 
condemnation of the teachings of Peter Abelard at the Council of Sens. After the election in 1145 of Pope 
Eugenius III, a Cistercian from Clairvaux, Bernard undertook preaching tours against heresy in the 
Languedoc, Bordeaux, Toulouse and Albis. From 1146 to 1147 he preached the <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">Second</span> Crusade, which 
subsequently failed in 1149. In this period he secured the acceptance of Hildegard’s writings at the Synod of 
Trier (1147-8). 

BERNARD SILVESTER Bernardus Silvestris, poet and philosopher. Of the same generation as William of 
Conches, Gilbert of Poitiers and John of Salisbury. Little is known of his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> apart from reminiscences of 
contemporaries. He taught at Tours, probably between 1130 and 1140, and had some connections with 
Chartres. His major <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> is the allegorical poem Cosmographia. 

BESANQON A papal embassy from Hadrian IV met Emperor Frederick Barbarossa and his chancellor, Rainald 
of Dassel, at the Diet (Assembly) of Besangon in October 1157, and a dispute arose over <span class="t10 t12 t16 t20 t21 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whether</span> the emperor 
should receive the imperial crown as a benefice (Latin beneficium) from the pope. Part of the problem may 
have been Rainald’s inflammatory translation of the ambiguous term benficium as ‘fief rather than as ‘gift’. 
The row provoked the emperor into asserting his rights by sacred Roman <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">law</span> to the <span class="t8 t11 t14 t19 hoverable">free</span> crown of the ‘holy 
empire’, and it contributed to the later schism between emperor and pope from 1159 to 1177. 

BOETHIUS (c. 480-C.524) The Roman statesman and Neoplatonist philosopher; author of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">works</span> on the Greek 
science of Euclid, Porphyry and Aristotle, as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as his prison writing The Consolation of Philosophy, which 
was widely read in the Middle Ages. In his theological writings, the Opuscula sacra, he wrote on the Trinity 
and the <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">Person</span> of Christ. 

BONIFACE, SAINT (c. 675-754) Wynfrith of Wessex, England, later known as Saint Boniface. The ‘Apostle of 
Germany’, he was martyred in 754 at Dokkum in Frisia. In c. 746 he had become the first Archbishop of 
Mainz. Since her convent lay <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the diocese of Mainz, Hildegard held the memory of Boniface in 
particular respect and wrote an antiphon in his honour. 

<span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">BOOK</span> OF <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">DIVINE</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">WORKS</span> Latin title Liber divinorum operum. Alternative title De operatione Dei (‘On the 
Activity of God’). Hildegard’s <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> large-scale visionary work, <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> in the period 1163-73/4 and divided 
into <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> parts covering the position of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> being, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> and the cosmos in the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> scheme of 
things. There are four manuscripts: (1) the Gent manuscript (Gent, University Library, cod. 241), important 
because it is evidently the original copy dictated or <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> by Hildegard and then heavily corrected; (2) 



Troyes, Bibliotheque municipale, cod. 683, originally from Clairvaux; (3) the Riesenkodex; and (4) the Lucca 
manuscript, important for its illustrations. 

<span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">BOOK</span> OF LIFE’S MERITS Latin title Liber vitae meritorum, sometimes translated as ‘The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of the Rewards 
of Life’. The <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> of Hildegard’s <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> visionary works, <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> in 1158-63, it centres on the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> figure 
of a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> looking out to different parts of the world. Especially concerned with ethical issues, five of its six 
parts or ‘books’ consist of dialogue-contests between 35 opposing pairs of vices and virtues, arranged in 
groups of five, seven or eight pairs. The theme of the sixth <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> is eschatology and the joys of heaven. Four 
of the six manuscripts are from the twelfth century and are associated with monasteries known to 
Hildegard: (1) the Dendermonde codex from the Abbey of Villers; (2) the Berlin manuscript (Berlin, SB 
Preuss. Kulturerbes cod. lat. theol. 727) associated with St Jacob in Mainz; (3) the Trier manuscript (Trier, 
Seminarbibliothek cod. 68) from the monastery of St Eucharius in Trier; and (4) the Riesenkodex from the 
Rupertsberg. 

CAESARIUS OF ARLES (c. 470-542) Writer and churchman. Archbishop of Arles from 502. His writings, 
particularly his sermons directed at a popular audience, were influential in the early medieval period. 

CALLISTUS <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span> Abbot John of Struma. The <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> ‘antipope’ of Frederick Barbarossa’s reign; elected in 1168 as 
successor to Paschal III. 

CANONS REGULAR or AUGUSTINIAN CANONS The Rule of St Augustine, a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">text</span> attributed to Augustine of 
Hippo, became popular during the pontificate of Gregory VII, and led to the foundation of communities of 
clerks known as canons regular, or Augustinian canons, in the eleventh century. 

CANOSSAThe castle near Reggio/Emilia in Northern Italy where Henry IV, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> of Germany, did penance 
before Pope Gregory <span class="t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t17 t19 t24 t25 t26 hoverable">VII</span> in February 1076. The event is emblematic of the strained relationship between 
emperor and pope which was to dog the political <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of the twelfth century. 

CATHARISM A religious movement that broke away from the Catholic Church and was condemned as heretical. 
The Cathars, i.e. the ‘pure ones’ (known in France as Albigensians), had extreme dualist beliefs, teaching 
that the <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> and diametrically opposed to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of the soul. 
While their clergy (‘the perfect’) were very ascetic, their laity (the ‘believers’) were reported to be extremely 
lax. The movement spread to Germany from the 1140s. Despite some unconscious dualist tendencies, 
Hildegard’s theology was based on the idea of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> being as a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> unity and as the centre of a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> 
creation, a microcosm of the wider macrocosm. Her sermon in Cologne during her <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> preaching tour 
(1161-3) specifically attacked the Cathars. 

CAUSE ET CURE Usually translated as ‘Causes and Cures’, although the Latin cura also means ‘care’. 
Alternative title Liber compositae medicine (‘The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of Composite Medicine’). Hildegard’s study of 
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">human</span> health, <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> 1151-8. <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t9 t11 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Together</span> with Physica, it may have originally formed a single <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> known as 
Liber subtilitatum diversarum naturarum creaturarum (‘The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of the Subtleties of the Diverse Natures 
of Creatures’). The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> survives in one thirteenth -century manuscript (Copenhagen, Kgl. Bibl., cod. 90b) 
and in a fragment of a manuscript (Berlin, SB Preuss. Kulturerbes, cod. lat. Qu. 674). 

CHARLEMAGNE (c. 742-814) Charles the Great, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> of Germany 768-814, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> coronation as Emperor in 
800 <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span> a stamp on the politics of medieval Europe. In 1165 he was canonized as a saint at the instigation of 
one of his powerful successors, Frederick Barbarossa, who sought thereby to gain prestige for his own 
position as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Holy</span> Roman Emperor. 

CHRISTIAN DE BUCH After the papal supporter Archbishop Conrad of Mainz fled the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">city</span> before the imperial 
forces, Frederick Barbarossa appointed Christian de Buch as Archbishop of Mainz. Christian was also the 
imperial chancellor and general of Frederick’s forces. He helped effect a reconciliation between the Emperor 
and the Pope at Venice in 1177 and was away in Rome when the prelates of Mainz imposed the interdict on 
the Rupertsberg in 1179. Hildegard eventually wrote to Christian asking him to lift the ban, and Christian 
agreed, placing the <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> in the <span class="t13 t23 hoverable">hands</span> of Philip, Archbishop of Cologne, the neighbouring diocese. But at 
the intervention of one of the Mainz prelates, the interdict was reinstated. Only after Hildegard had appealed 
to Christian in a <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> letter was the ban lifted; Christian sent Hildegard a personal apology. 



CISTERCIAN <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">ORDER</span> A twelfth-century reform movement based on Benedictine monasticism, the Cistercians 
questioned both the elaborate liturgy and the close connections with the feudal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> which had developed 
in the earlier Cluniac movement. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> emphasized meditative reading and manual labour as important 
features of a monk’s daily life, but also inspired literary talent, particularly in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">works</span> of Bernard of 
Clairvaux and ZElred of Rievaulx. 

CITEAUX (Latin name: Cistercium) Monastery near Dijon in France, founded by Robert of Molesmes in 1098; 
the mother <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> of the Cistercian movement, efficiently organized by its abbot Stephen Harding from 1108. 

CLUNIACS An important movement for the reform of the Benedictine monastic <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">order</span> in the eleventh and early 
twelfth centuries. The Cluniacs advocated a close adherence to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of the Benedictine Rule, along with 
extremely elaborate and splendid worship, which <span class="t3 t13 t18 t24 hoverable">left</span> little <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> for manual labour (for which they came to 
be criticized). Their principles inspired Pope Gregory VU’s reforms, especially against simony and clerical 
marriage. An important Cluniac reformer in the twelfth century was Peter the Venerable, who clashed with 
Bernard of Clairvaux. 

CLUNY Near Macon in Burgundy, France; the monastery, founded in 909/10, became the centre of the Cluniac 
reform. 

CONRAD <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> and Emperor of Germany from 1137 to 1152. As a member of the Hohenstaufen dynasty, his 
election to the throne in preference to the Welf Henry the Proud, Duke of Bavaria and Saxony, led to rivalry 
between the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> factions. Hildegard wrote a letter of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> encouragement to Conrad in 1150. 

CONRAD, ARCHBISHOP OF MAINZ (1161-5 and 1183-1200) Conrad (or Konrad) of Wittelsbach, brother of 
Duke Otto of Bavaria. Conrad is one of the named witnesses of the imperial edict of protection for the 
Rupertsberg convent on 14 April 1163. Although his election as Archbishop of Mainz had been pushed by 
Frederick Barbarossa, Conrad nevertheless supported the Pope, and in 1164 on the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> of the antipope 
Victor IV urged Barbarossa to come to terms with Alexander III. On 23 May 1165, at the imperial court held 
in Wiirzburg, he refused to recognize the new antipope Paschal III; Barbarossa reacted by removing him 
from office and replacing him with Christian de Buch. Conrad fled to Alexander in France and then to Rome, 
where he was appointed Cardinal Bishop of S. Sabina. From 1169 he was active as a papal legate, and after 
the <span class="t13 hoverable">Peace</span> of Venice in 1177, he renounced his claim to the archbishopric of Mainz until the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> of 
Christian in 1183. 

CREMONA Venue of the Synod in 1148 at which Arnold of Brescia was excommunicated, shortly after 
Hildegard’s writings were approved at the Synod of Trier. 

CRUSADES The series of expeditions, often inspired by public sermons on the ‘taking of the Cross’, which 
aimed to recover the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Holy</span> Lands, <span class="t28 hoverable">Jerusalem</span> and Palestine, from Islam and retain them as part of 
Christendom. The First Crusade (1095-99) was a notable success, but the second, preached by Bernard of 
Clairvaux in 1146-7, came to a disastrous end in 1149. In 1187 Saladin <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> Jerusalem, which led to the 
moderately successful <span class="t7 hoverable">Third</span> Crusade (1189-92), in which Richard the Lionheart of England, Philip II of 
France, and Emperor Frederick Barbarossa of Germany all <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> part. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span> Anselm of Canterbury in the 
eleventh century was opposed to such ventures, most writers in Hildegard’s <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> seem to have supported the 
aims of the Crusades. 

DENDERMONDE A monastery in Belgium. Codex 9 of its library is the manu-script originally owned by the 
monastery of Villers in Hildegard’s lifetime which contains the oldest version of Hildegard’s Symphonia and 
an important copy of The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of Life’s Merits. 

DISIBOD A seventh-century Irish bishop who retired to a hermitage near the confluence of the rivers Nahe and 
Gian in the Rhineland. Despite founding a monastery on the hill overlooking the site, he remained in the 
hermitage until his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> at the age of 81. Hildegard held him in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> respect, writing a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Life</span> ofDisibod and 
several songs in his honour. 

DISBODENBERG The hill and site of the monastery founded by the Irishman Disibod in the early Middle Ages 
and refounded at the beginning of the twelfth century. It was here that Hildegard began her monastic <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> as 
a child recluse under the tutelage of Jutta of Spanheim. The records disagree as to when they moved there: 



no6 according to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Life</span> of Hildegard or 1112 according to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Life</span> offutta. The anchorage eventually 
became a community of nuns with Jutta as abbess; in effect, the institution became a double monastery of 
monks and nuns under the final authority of the abbot. Hildegard succeeded Jutta as abbess of the convent 
in 1136, remaining there until she founded the autonomous community on the Rupertsberg in about 1150. 

EBERHARD, BISHOP OF BAMBERG Elected Bishop in 1146 and consecrated by Pope Eugenius III. Eberhard 
had <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> relations with Frederick Barbarossa, taking part in the Italian campaigns, and as a reward for his 
support, the abbey of Niederalteich was placed under the control of the bishopric of Bamberg. In 1157 he 
responded to a request from Hildegard and provided a building in Bamberg as a new convent for the <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> of 
Gertrud of Stahleck and her fellow nuns. In 1163 he was the fifth witness on the imperial deed of protection 
for the Rupertsberg. 

EBERHARD, BISHOP OF SALZBURG <span class="t16 t24 hoverable">Born</span> in 1085, Eberhard of Biburg and Hipoltstein became a canon in 
Bamberg, a monk at Priifening and then an abbot of Biburg in the diocese of Regensburg. On 22 May 1149, 
he was consecrated Bishop of Salzburg. Politically active, his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> pleased Conrad III, although he did not 
frequent the imperial court as much as his friend Eberhard of Bamberg. During the schism, he supported 
Pope Alexander <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span> and opposed the election of antipopes such as Victor IV in 1162. Nevertheless, he 
remained a presence among Frederick Barbarossa’s followers and acted as a mediator between emperor and 
pope. In 1163, he attended the imperial court at Mainz, and was the <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> witness on the imperial deed of 
protection for the Rupertsberg. 

ECKBERT (EKBERT) OF SCHONAU (d.1184) Writer and preacher. Brother and adviser of the visionary 

Elisabeth of Schonau. From 1140 to 1146 he studied in Paris, where he was friends with Rainald of Dassel. 

He subsequently became a canon at St Cassius in Bonn, but after a pilgrimage to Rome in 1155 he became a 
priest and then, after persuasion by Elisabeth, a monk, joining the double monastery at Schonau. He 
eventually became abbot there. Among his many writings, he composed Thirteen Sermons against the 
Cathars, and he preached against this movement at Bonn before 1153, at Cologne in 1163 and at Koblenz in 
1167. 

EIBINGEN Founded by Hildegard c. 1165; a daughter monastery of the Rupertsberg. 

ELISABETH OF SCHONAU (d. 1164) A visionary author who, like many others, experienced most of her visions 
in a <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> of ecstatic trance (in marked contrast to Hildegard’s waking state). From 1147 a nun at Schonau. 
Her early visions, from 1152 to 1155, are devotional pieces on the lives of <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Christ</span> and Mary. But from 1155, 
she employed her brother Eckbert to put her compositions down in writing, and under his influence the 
writings become more theological and doctrinal. Her main <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">works</span> are a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> influenced by Scivias known as 
The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of the Ways of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> (compiled in 1156-7), an elaboration of the Ursula legend entitled The 
Revelations of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Holy</span> Army of the Virgins of Cologne (1156-7) and a visionary treatise in support of the 
doctrine of the bodily resurrection of Mary (1156-9). Elisabeth corresponded with the older Hildegard for 
support and encouragement. She became magistra (abbess) of her community in 1157. 

ERIGENA (ERIUGENA) John the Scot (c. 810-c. 877). Theologian and philosopher who attempted to reconcile 
the Neoplatonist idea of emanation (i.e. the origin of everything that exists from the One) with the Christian 
idea of creation. His greatest work, Periphyseon, or the Division of Nature, was possibly known to 
Hildegard; she perhaps knew his ideas through excerpts in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">works</span> of Honorius of Autun. 

EUGENIUS <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span> (d. 1153) Bernardo Pignatelli of Pisa, elected Pope in 1145. In 1135 he had joined the Cistercian 
Abbey of Clairvaux under Bernard. On his election as Pope he refused to recognize the Roman Senate and 
had to flee from Rome to Farfa and Viterbo and then in 1147 to France, where he commissioned Bernard to 
preach the <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">Second</span> Crusade. Eugenius held synods at Paris (1147), Trier (1147-8) where he personally read 
out and approved Hildegard’s writings, Rheims (1148) where Gilbert Porreta’s writings were scrutinized for 
heresy, and Cremona (1148), where he excommunicated Arnold of Brescia, now leader of the Senate. In 1149 
he was able to return briefly to Rome, and again in 1153, when he died there. Essentially a reformer and 
pious Cistercian, he exchanged a <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of letters with Hildegard after the Synod of Trier. 

FREDERICK BARBAROSSA, OR FREDERICK 1 (c. 1122-90) Frederick (Friedrich) of Swabia. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> and Emperor 
of Germany. Elected <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> on the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> of his uncle, Conrad III, in 1152, he united the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> rival dynasties 



through his mother, a Guelph (Welf), and his father, a Hohenstaufen. In 1153 he signed a treaty of mutual 
support with Pope Eugenius <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span> at Constance, and on 18 June 1155 he was crowned Emperor by Pope 
Hadrian IV, who honoured the Treaty of Constance. But relations between emperor and pope soon changed. 
Hadrian changed his policies and became reconciled with the Norman <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> of Sicily, William I, at the 
Concordat of Benevento, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> breaking the terms of the Treaty of Constance. At the Diet of Besangon in 
1157, Frederick insisted on the emperor’s rule of a ‘holy empire’, as against the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> jurisdiction of the 
pope (this eventually <span class="t16 hoverable">created</span> the title of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Holy</span> Roman Emperor). After the papal election of 1159, he 
supported the ‘antipope’ Victor IV against Pope Alexander III, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> isolating himself from Italy, France and 
the Anglo-Norman world. The schism lasted almost eighteen <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> and led to bitter hostilities, including 
military action by imperial troops in German lands against monastic supporters of the pope. With the aim of 
establishing an imperial <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> in Lombardy, Barbarossa undertook six major Italian expeditions. In 1162 he 
<span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> Milan. In 1167 he captured Rome, but had to withdraw because of a malaria epidemic. In the end, he 
failed to break the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of the Lombard communes and after his defeat at Legnano in 1176, he submitted to 
Pope Alexander III. In 1181 he overthrew a rival in Germany, Henry the Lion, the <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">head</span> of the Welf dynasty, 
and increased his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> by the marriage in 1186 of his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">son</span> Henry to Constance, heiress of Norman Sicily. 
Frederick Barbarossa died while on the <span class="t7 hoverable">Third</span> Crusade in 1189. 

GEBENO OF EBERBACH Eberbach, in the Rheingau, was a large Cistercian monastery with which Hildegard 
had personal contacts. She wrote to Abbot Ruthard in the 1150s and sent a letter of encouragement to the 
monks in the 1160s, a period when monasteries supporting the pope suffered oppression from imperial 
troops. In 1220, Prior Gebeno of Eberbach composed his Mirror of Future Times, or Pentachronon (i.e. The 
Five Ages), much of which consists of extracts from Hildegard’s apocalyptic or prophetic writings, including 
such correspondence as the letter to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Conrad <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span> (c. 1150; 34) and the letter to the Cologne clerics (c. 
1163). With its one-sided <span class="t1 t2 t19 hoverable">view</span> of the range of her writings, the Pentachronon became the most widely 
known collection of Hildegard’s <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> in the later Middle Ages. 

GERALD OF WALES (Latin name: Giraldus Cambrensis) (c. 1146-1223) Writer, historian and churchman. 

GERTRUD OF STAHLECK (d. 1191) Sister of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Conrad <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span> and Barbarossa’s aunt. Friend and correspondent 
of Hildegard. Her husband Hermann of Stahleck was a generous supporter of Hildegard’s convent at 
Rupertsberg. After his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> in 1156, Gertrud became a nun first at Wechterswinkel in the diocese of 
Wurzburg and then, after Hildegard’s intervention with Bishop Eberhard of Bamberg, at the new foundation 
of St Theodore and St Mary at Bamberg. 

GILBERT PORRETA (c. 1080-1154) Otherwise known as Gilbert de la Porree or Gilbert of Poitiers. Biblical 
commentator and scholastic theologian. After studying under Bernard of Chartres and Anselm of Laon, he 
became a well-known <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">master</span> at Paris. In 1142 he was appointed Bishop of Poitiers. Interested in logic and 
the language of theology, his statements in his commentary on Boethius’s opuscula that ‘God is one’ and 
‘God is three’ led to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> controversy, particularly at the Synod of Rheims in 1148. Hildegard was involved in 
this debate when asked for advice on the <span class="t25 hoverable">matter</span> by a <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">master</span> of Paris, Odo of Soissons, in a letter <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">written</span> 
between 1148 and 1150 (see 32; and for Hildegard’s reply, see 4). 

GOTTFRIED OF DISIBODENBERG (Latin name: Godefridus monachus) The monk of Disibodenberg who 
became Hildegard’s secretary in 1174, a year after the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> of Volmar. His <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Life</span> of Hildegard was incomplete 
when he died in 1176, and was finished by Theoderich of Echternach. 

GOTTFRIED OF STRASSBURG Middle <span class="t23 hoverable">High</span> German poet. Author of the Arthurian epic Tristan (c. 1210). 

GREGORY THE <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">GREAT</span> (c. 540-604) From 590 Pope Gregory I. Regarded in the Middle Ages along with 

Ambrose, Augustine and Jerome as one of the four <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> ‘Doctors of the Church’. His many writings include 
the Moralia (a commentary on Job), homilies on the gospels, and the Pastoral Care, a guide to the 
psychology of teaching and ministry. 

GREGORY VII, POPE (1073-85) Hildebrand, a native of Tuscany (born between 1015 and 1034), became one of 
the most influential popes of the period. At the Lenten Synod of 1074, he issued decrees against simony, i.e. 
the payment of money to promote <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> to <span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">higher</span> offices in the Church, and against clerical marriage. He 



also sought to gain exclusive control over the appointment of bishops. This led to the ‘investiture 
controversy’, for he was almost immediately opposed by the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> of the German Empire, Henry IV, who 
wished to retain investiture along with royal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> over bishops. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> and bitter disputes between pope 
and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> continued in the twelfth century, with frequent papal excommunications of the German kings, who 
reacted by electing their own ‘antipopes’. 

GREGORY IX (c. 1148-1241) Pope from 1227. During his pontificate, in 1233, the canonization protocol was 
commissioned to provide evidence for Hildegard’s sanctity. This was rejected on its completion and returned 
for revision in 1237, but the revised version apparently never reached Pope Innocent IV, who wrote a letter 
in 1243 asking for the new claim to be submitted. 

GUIBERT OF GEMBLOUX (German name: Wibert) (1124/5-1213) Writer and monk of Gembloux near Namur 
in Flanders. Extremely learned, he was considerably influenced by the Latin classics in his style of writing. 
During the 1170s, Hildegard’s reputation reached Guibert and he became a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> admirer of her work. From 
1175, therefore, he began a correspondence with her which culminated in a visit to the Rupertsberg in the 
autumn of that year. He also prepared the Thirty-Eight Questions with the monks of the monastery of 
Villers and sent it to Hildegard in 1176. From 1177 Guibert served as Hildegards secretary until her <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> in 
1179; he returned to Gembloux in 1180. In 1188/9 he was Abbot of Florennes near Namur and then from 
1194 Abbot of Gembloux. 

HADRIAN IV, POPE (c. 1100-59) Nicholas Breakspear, the only English Pope. In 1154, he secured the expulsion 
of Arnold of Brescia from Rome and in 1155 obtained homage from Frederick Barbarossa before agreeing to 
his coronation as Emperor. In 1157 his legates met Frederick at Besangon and delivered his claim that the 
Emperor held his position as a ‘benefice’ from the Pope. This led to a severe dispute, which eventually 
became a schism during the pontificate of Alexander III. Hildegard wrote an admonitory letter to him on his 
election to the papal see in 1154. 

HARTWIG, ARCHBISHOP OF BREMEN Hartwig of Stade, Archbishop of Bremen 1148-68. His sister was 

Richardis of Stade, the nun and friend of Hildegard at Disibodenberg. Their parents were Rudolf I, Margrave 
of Stade in North Germany (d. 1124) and Margravine (or Marchioness) Richardis, originally of Spanheim- 
Lavanttal (d. 1151); the Margravine’s <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> cousin was Jutta of Spanheim. After the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> of his brother 
Rudolf in 1144, Hartwig was involved in an inheritance dispute with Henry the Lion, Duke of Saxony, who 
imprisoned him. On his appointment in 1148, he aimed to extend the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of his archbishopric in 
Scandinavia and then north-east Germany, in 1149 reestablishing the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> bishoprics of Oldenburg, 
Mecklenburg and Ratzburg. But at the Diet of Goslar in 1154 Henry the Lion was given the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> to invest 
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> bishops, despite Hartwig’s protests. In the same year he fell into disfavour with Frederick 
Barbarossa for refusing to perform military service on the imperial expedition to Italy. In 1166 he supported 
the revolt in Saxony against Henry the Lion. 

HEINRICH, ARCHBISHOP OF MAINZ (1142-53) As <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">head</span> of the local diocese, Heinrich was at first a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> 
encourager for Hildegard. He supported her at the Synod of Trier of 1147-8, and at the instigation of 
Richardis’s mother, Margravine Richardis of Spanheim-Lavanttal, he persuaded Abbot Kuno of 
Disibodenberg to allow Hildegard to found the abbey at Rupertsberg. On 1 May 1152, he consecrated the new 
church there, but the same year saw the demise of his career when he failed to support the election of 
Frederick Barbarossa as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> and Emperor. In 1153 Heinrich was deposed, despite an appeal from Hildegard 
to Pope Eugenius III. 

HEINRICH OF VELDEKE Author of the Middle <span class="t23 hoverable">High</span> German poem Eneit (1170s), based on classical sources; 
an early example of the vernacular literature that was beginning to flourish at the end of Hildegard’s career. 

HELENGER Abbot of Disibodenberg (1155-79). A regular correspondent with Hildegard. 

HENRY II <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> of England (1154-89). 

HENRY IV (or HEINRICH IV) (1050-1106) <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> and Emperor of Germany from 1056, he was declared of age in 
1065. His reign is characterized by wars with the rebel Saxon princes and conflicts with Pope Gregory VII, 
particularly over the investiture of bishops and abbots. In 1077 he submitted to the Pope at Canossa, but the 



conflict was later renewed. Henry installed an antipope Clement <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span> at Rome in 1084, who crowned him 
Emperor in the same year. 

HENRY v Henry IV’s successor (1106-25). During his reign the investiture controversy was settled at the 
Concordat of Worms (1122). 

HENRY VI <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> of Germany and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Holy</span> Roman Emperor (1190-7). Frederick Barbarossa’s successor. 

HENRY OF LIEGE (German name: Heinrich von Liittich) Henry of Leyen, probably a monk at Bilsen near 
Maastricht. Served as Bishop of Liege 1145-64. He was loyal to the Emperor, and his name appears on many 
of Frederick Barbarossa’s charters. He <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> part in the first Italian expedition of 1154, attending the 
Emperor’s coronation in 1155. In 1163, he was to be the seventh witness on the imperial deed of protection 
for the Rupertsberg convent. 

HENRY THE LION (1129-95) Duke of Saxony and Bavaria and <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">head</span> of the Welf dynasty. At first enjoying <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> 
relations with the Emperor, Frederick Barbarossa, he <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> part in the first Italian campaign of 1154 and 1155 
and in return was given back the duchy of Bavaria by Barbarossa in 1156. He expanded Saxony eastwards, 
developing Liineburg, Bremen, Lubeck and Braunschweig (Brunswick). He was a lifelong enemy of Hartwig 
of Bremen, with whom he disputed the jurisdiction of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> north-eastern bishoprics. In 1166 he was 
opposed by a League of princes and then finally in 1180 by Barbarossa. He was exiled twice (1181-5, 1189- 
90) and became reconciled to the Emperor (Henry VI) in 1194. 

HERMANN, BISHOP OF CONSTANCE Imperial supporter. Served as Bishop of Constance in southern Germany 
to 1166. In 1140, Hermann corresponded with Bernard of Clairvaux, who warned him of Arnold of Brescia, at 
that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> in Constance. In March 1153 he presided over the wedding ceremony of Frederick Barbarossa and 
Adelheid of Vohburg. In 1154 he <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> part in the Italian campaign and as a result had all his properties 
confirmed by the Emperor in 1155. On 22 May he was one of many bishops who supported the antipope 
Paschal III. Hildegard’s letters to Hermann are critical and admonitory. 

HERMAS Christian visionary author of the <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> century. The Shepherd of Hermas appears to have influenced 
Hildegard with its emphasis on visions, its teaching on the virtues, and its <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> of architectural imagery as in 
the later parts of Scivias. 

HERRAD OF LANDSBERG (d. 1196) Female writer and from about 1178 <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">head</span> of a community of Augustinian 
canons at Hohenbourg near Strassbourg. Author and compiler of the illustrated theological textbook, The 
Garden of Delights (1160s and 70s). 

HONORIUS ‘OF AUTUN’ Popular writer on theology active in the early twelfth century. Probably not from 
Autun, he possibly became a monk in Germany and spent <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> in England, where he composed his 
Elucidarium, a survey of Christian doctrine with parallels to Hildegard’s Scivias in coverage of themes. His 
later <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> Gemma animae uses allegory and symbolism to discuss the liturgy, while his Imago mundi treats 
cosmology and geography. 

HUGH OF ST VICTOR (d. 1142) Theologian at St Victor, a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> of Augustinian canons in Paris, which he 
joined in about 1115. Author of the large survey of doctrine The Sacraments of the Christian Faith, the 
mystical treatise TheAi'k of Noah and the widely <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> textbook on the arts known as Didascalicon. 

HUGO (d. 1177) One of Hildegard’s brothers. Cathedral cantor at Mainz. He assisted Hildegard for a short 
period as secretary after the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> of Gottfried of Disibodenberg. 

JOACHIM OF FIORE (c. 1135-1202) Biblical commentator and writer, with a strong interest in mysticism and 
prophecy, particularly his idea of the ‘three ages’ of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> corresponding to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> persons of the 
Trinity. At first a monk of the Benedictine, and later Cistercian, monastery of Corazzo, he unwillingly agreed 
to be elected Abbot in 1177 but eventually retired, with papal approval, to the Sila mountains in 1196. 

JOHN OF SALISBURY (c. 1115-80) Humanist, writer and churchman. After studying in Paris under Abelard, 
William of Conches and Gilbert Porreta, he entered the diplomatic service of Theobald, Archbishop of 
Canterbury, from 1147 and of Thomas Becket from 1161. In December 1170 he was present in Canterbury 
when Becket was murdered by Henry II’s men. From 1176 he was Bishop of Chartres, and he <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> part in the 
<span class="t7 hoverable">Third</span> Lateran Council in 1179. His writings include the political study Policraticus, the textbook Metalog icon 



and the History of the Popes. 

JUTTA OF SPANHEIM (or SPONHEIM) Daughter of Count Stephan of Spanheim and member of an influential 
Rhineland family. With a clear vocation for the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of a recluse, she became guardian to the eight-year-old 
Hildegard after her parents had dedicated her to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> life. She was later Abbess of the convent at 
Disibodenberg until her <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> in 1136. Her brother Count Meginhard of Spanheim gave financial and 
material assistance to the foundation of Hildegard’s convent at Rupertsberg in the 1150s. 

KUNO Abbot of Disibodenberg from 1136 to 1155. 

KURENBERG Twelfth-century poet from Austria. Known as ‘der von Kiirenberg’, he wrote in Middle <span class="t23 hoverable">High</span> 
German rather than Latin. Author of the celebrated ‘Falcon Song’ (1160s). 

LAMPRECHT German writer, a pioneer in the <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> of the vernacular. He wrote his poem Alexander in the 1140s. 

LINGUA IGNOTA Hildegard’s ‘Unknown Language’, compiled as a glossary in the period 1151-8. 

LUCCA MANUSCRIPT A thirteenth-century manuscript held at Lucca (Bibl. Governativa, cod. 1942) containing 
a series of illustrations to The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span> Works. 

LUDWIG OF TRIER Abbot of St Eucharius in Trier and personal acquaintance of Hildegard. Along with 
Gottfried of Echternach, Ludwig commissioned Theoderich to write the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Life</span> of Hildegard in the 1180s. 

MACROBIUS Macrobius Ambrosius Theodosius, fifth-century Roman writer. Author of The Dream ofScipio, a 
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> on number-mysticism, oracles, virtue, astronomy, music, geography and the soul. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> was widely 
read in the Middle Ages and helped to transmit Neoplatonist ideas to the Latin West. 

MARIE DE FRANCE A contemporary woman author of very different inclinations from Hildegard’s, who wrote 
tales of chivalry and romance in her native French. She probably lived in England. 

ODO OF SOISSONS, or ODO OF PARIS A <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t12 t17 t19 t20 t27 t29 hoverable">master</span> at Paris who wrote to Hildegard in 1148 to <span class="t11 t12 t22 t25 t27 hoverable">find</span> out her 
understanding of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> and the Trinity as discussed at the controversial Council of Rheims, 
where Gilbert Porreta withdrew some of his more audacious statements on the question. 

ORDO VIRTUTUM Hildegard’s ‘Play of the Virtues’, originally conceived in a shorter version in the final vision 
of <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> 3 of Scivias and rewritten as a separate play or opera in the period 1151-8. 

PASCHAL <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span> Guido of Crema. At the instigation of Rainald of Dassel, imperial chancellor, he was elected 
antipope in 1164 after the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> of Victor IV. At Christmas 1165, he canonized Charlemagne. On his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> in 
1168 he was succeeded by a further antipope, Callistus III. 

PETER LOMBARD (c. 1100-60) Theologian and teacher at Paris from 1143 or 1144. He attended the Council of 
Rheims in 1148, where he opposed Gilbert Porreta. Author of the Sentences, a classic textbook of medieval 
theology arranged in four books to cover (1) the Trinity, (2) <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t9 t12 t15 t16 t17 t19 t22 t24 t25 t26 hoverable">creation</span> and sin, (3) the incarnation and virtues, 
(4) the sacraments and the four last things. 

PHYSICA Alternative title Liber simplicis medicinae (‘Book of Simple Medicine’). <span class="t0 t11 t24 hoverable">Written</span> 1151-8. Hildegard’s 
survey of the phenomena of the natural <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> (plants, metals, stones etc.) and their medicinal uses. 
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t9 t11 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Together</span> with Causes and Cures, it may have originally formed a single <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> known as Liber subtilitatum 
diversarum naturarum creaturarum (‘The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">Book</span> of the Subtleties of the Diverse Natures of Creatures’). 
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Three</span> complete manuscripts survive, one from the thirteenth and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> from the fifteenth centuries. 

PRUDENTIUS Aurelius Clemens Prudentius (348-c. 410). Christian poet of the late Roman Empire. Apart from 
his hymns, he is best known for his Psychomachia, an allegorical poem about the struggle of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Soul</span> and 
the Church, in which seven vices are overcome by the powers of seven virtues. 

PTOLEMY Claudius Ptolemaeus. Greek astronomer writing at Alexandria from AD 146 to 170. His writings, 
especially his textbook the Almagest, were particularly influential. 

RAINALD OF DASSEL (c. 1118/20-67) Important politician in Germany. In 1153 he was part of the embassy 
sent to Eugenius <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span> in Rome; from 1156 he was Chancellor of the German Empire and from 1159 
Archbishop of Cologne. Between 1158 and 1164 he led the imperial troops on their expeditions to Italy. It 
was his reading of the pope’s letter at the Diet of Besangon that led to a rift between emperor and pope. 
During the schism his excommunication by Alexander <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span> in 1163 led to his insistence on the election of a 



new antipope, Paschal III, in 1164. 

RICHARDIS (d. 1151) Richardis, Margravine (Marchioness) of Spanheim-Lavanttal. Influential noblewoman, 
widow of Rudolf I of Stade, mother of the nun Richardis and of the churchman Hartwig of Bremen, 
grandmother and guardian of Adelheid of Gandersheim. Related to Jutta of Spanheim. She intervened on 
Hildegard’s behalf with Archbishop Heinrich of Mainz to gain his support for the move to Rupertsberg. 

RICHARDIS OF STADE (d. 1152) A nun of Hildegard’s community and a close friend and assistant. Richardis 
<span class="t3 t13 t18 t24 hoverable">left</span> Rupertsberg to become the Abbess of Bassum in 1151, which led to an emotional dispute recorded in a 
<span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of highly personal letters (see 12). 

RIESENKODEX (i.e. ‘Giant Codex’) The large compilation of Hildegard’s <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">works</span> copied at the Rupertsberg after 
her death. The <span class="t1 t4 t7 t15 t18 t20 t27 hoverable">book</span> is manuscript 2 in the collection of the Hessische Landesbibliothek in Wiesbaden, 
Germany. 

RUPERT OF DEUTZ (c. 1075-1129) A monk of Liege who became Abbot of Deutz near Cologne in 1120. His 
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of 1125, On the <span class="t0 t7 t21 t27 hoverable">Glory</span> and Honour of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Son</span> of Man, a commentary on Matthew, mentions visions 
which, rather like Hildegard, he had experienced for a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> revealing this to others. 

RUPERT, SAINT A legendary young prince in the Rhineland during the Carolingian period who became devout 
after a pilgrimage to Rome at the age of fifteen, whereupon he gave away his property and built churches 
and hospices on his extensive lands. After his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> aged twenty his mother Bertha founded a monastery in 
his honour at the Rupertsberg. 

RUPERTSBERG A hill overlooking the junction of the River Nahe with the Rhine at Bingen. The site of a shrine 
to Saint Rupert which was destroyed by the Vikings in the ninth century. Hildegard decided to locate her 
independent monastery there and moved from the Disibodenberg with a group of her nuns in about 1150. 

RUPERTSBERG SCIVIAS, THE The famous Rupertsberg copy of Scivias (Wiesbaden, Hessische 

Landesbibliothek, manuscript 1) with illustrations done by artists probably under the direction of Hildegard 
herself. Lost in 1945, its <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">text</span> and artwork are preserved in photocopies and a colour facsimile at the Abbey of 
St Hildegard at Eibingen. 

SALEM SCIVIAS, THE The twelfth-century Salem Scivias, with a different <span class="t0 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span> of illustrations from those in the 
Rupertsberg manuscript. Now in Heidelberg University Library, cod. Sal. X 16. 

SCIVIAS (‘KNOW THE WAYS’) Hildegard’s first major <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> (1141-51), an encyclopedic survey of salvation 
history and Church doctrine, divided into <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> parts or ‘books’ of six, seven and thirteen visions 
respectively. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> survives in ten complete manuscripts, six of them from the twelfth century, including 
the illustrated Rupertsberg and Salem manuscripts. 

TENGSWICH OF ANDERNACH Tengswich, or Tengswindis, was Mistress of Sankt Marien, a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> of canons 
regular at Andernach in the Rhine Valley north of Bingen. In a letter dated 1148-50 (no. 52 in the Collected 
Letters ), Tengswich criticized Hildegard’s hierarchical attitudes, in particular her refusal to allow girls from 
lower down the social scale to join her community at Disibodenberg. She also asked <span class="t10 t12 t16 t20 t21 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whether</span> it was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> that 
on feast <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 hoverable">days</span> Hildegard allowed her nuns to wear rings and diadems decorated with allegorical figures. This 
question, it is thought, may reflect accounts <span class="t13 t14 t15 t18 t27 hoverable">heard</span> by Tengswich of a performance of The Play of the Virtues. 

THEODORIC (THEODERICH) OF ECHTERNACH Monk and writer from Echternach (now in Luxembourg). 
Author of the <span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">second</span> and <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> books of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Life</span> of Hildegard, begun originally by Gottfried of 
Disibodenberg but not finished by the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> of his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> in 1176. Theoderich was commissioned to do the 
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> by Ludwig of St Eucharius in Trier, a personal friend of Hildegard, and by Abbot Gottfried of 
Echternach. It was completed in the 1180s. 

THOMAS A BECKET St Thomas Becket (c. 1120-70). From 1155 Chancellor of England under Henry II, he 
resigned when he was elected Archbishop of Canterbury in 1162. After his murder in 1170 by Henry’s men, 
he was canonized by Pope Alexander II in 1173. 

TIMAEUS Plato’s <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> on cosmology; known in Western Europe in the twelfth century through a Latin 
translation by Chalcidius. 

URSULA, SAINT According to the legend current in Hildegard’s day, St Ursula was a British princess of the dark 



ages who renounced her marriage and travelled with 11,000 virgins on a pilgrimage to Rome. On their return 
journey, they were massacred by the barbarian Huns at Cologne. In the early twelfth century an old 
cemetery was uncovered in which they were supposedly buried, and their relics, a <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> token of their 
virtue and influence, were widely distributed. 

VICTOR IV Octavian of Santa Cecilia. Italian churchman and antipope (1159-64). In 1151 he was a papal legate 
to Germany and in 1155 led the advance guard at the coronation of Frederick Barbarossa in Rome. In 1159 he 
was involved in the disputed papal election with Roland (Alexander III), which began the eighteen-year 
schism <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the Western Church. 

VOLMAR (d. 1173) Monk of Disibodenberg. The first to encourage Hildegard in her writing, he became her 
secretary and moved with her to the Rupertsberg. 

WILLIAM OF CONCHES (c. 1080-c. 1154) Philosopher and Christian humanist; pupil of Bernard of Chartres. 
His <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t25 t29 hoverable">works</span> include commentary glosses on Priscian’s Institutions of Grammar, Plato’s Timaeus, and 
Boethius’s Consolation of Philosophy .
